definitions.definition: to make something look more attractive by putting things on it

examples.text: They decorated the room with flowers and balloons.
The cake was decorated to look like a car.
The family gets together on Christmas Eve to decorate the tree.

definitions.definition: to put paint, wallpaper, etc. on the walls and ceilings of a room or house
definitions.labels: (especially British English)(British English)(especially North American English)(British English)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(especially British English)(British English)(British English)(especially British English)(especially British English)(North American English usually)

examples.text: Sorry about the mess—we've just started decorating.
to decorate a room/a wall/a house/an apartment
We need to decorate the sitting room.
These villas come fully **furnished and decorated**.
The room is decorated in pale blues and greens.
The dining room is decorated in a modern style.

definitions.definition: to be placed on something in order to make it look more attractive

examples.text: Photographs of actors decorated the walls of the restaurant.

definitions.definition: to give somebody an award or medal as a sign of respect for something they have done

examples.text: She was decorated for her efforts during the war.
the most highly decorated unit in the British Army

wordOrigin: mid 16th cent. (in the sense ‘to grace or honour’): from Latin decoratus ‘embellished’ (past participle of decorare), from decus, decor- ‘beauty, honour, or embellishment’.
